content.description: This is located on the north facing wall just west of Cheers on a face to the right of a flake system (Situational Distress) and an arete (Insane Pilot).  Look for a belay bolt at the bottom.  Climb up and over two small roofs.
content.protection: Mixed. 4 bolts. Metolius Rap Hanger anchors.

content.description: This route is on the far end of Boot Hill south, just past Fireplace, same elevation on a small face.
The crux is at the first two bolts.After making several hard bouldering type moves and clipping the third bolt,the climbing is about 5.8 to the top.
content.location: This climb is located on a buttress on the far left end of Boothill near the Green Monster.Climb is #4.

content.description: The route follows some crack systems in a corner, past a small tree to the top.
content.protection: This route sucks up the gear and is a great trad lead.  Use the anchors for lichen/leap.

content.description: Short face climb, just past Fireplace on the far southern end of Boot Hill.The names of these climbs are in tribute to the movie:"TOUCHING THE VOID"I would like to name the wall "ALPINE FACE"However it has not been named yet.

Interesting climbing for 20 feet, then easy climbing to the chains. "Trad" only because of the 20-30 feet between the last bolt and the chains. You could could protect this part with a medium cam or two.
content.protection: 3 bolts. Place a medium cam or two between the third bolt and the chain anchors, if you wish to protect a runout on easy climbing.
content.location: After scrambling up the gully right of "Dunka Dunk", head south for about 100 meters. This will be the first bolted line your encounter, on a relatively small pinnacle called "Fireplace". Shares anchors with "F...n' Battery" to its right.

content.description: Corner climb,the 2nd on TR should clean draws.

Climbing is on stellar green rock with fun roof moves half way up.  There are some extremely closely spaced bolts on this climb (very un-Mt.Lemmon) that can cause dangerous rope rubbing if the leader lowers off.  Better to save fraying your rope and rap.  Well worth climbing.
Location: Boot Hill south, to the right of existing climbBlood Mary.Short, fun face climb.

This is a good lead route, but you need to "tram" yourselfin on top rope, since it is a corner climb.This climb is immediatly to the right of Obsessed Driller.These two climbs were established on New Years Day 2005By Andy Peters and J.Miller
Start up gap between rocks and onto ledge then up.  Gets a little grungy at the top.  It'd be a decent first lead.
content.location: Leftmost route on the wall above and right of the Green Monster Crack.

content.description: Fun route over big blocks.
content.location: Rightmost route on Brickyard (first wall at the end of the trail).

content.description: This is located to the right of Leap Frog, on the other side of a gap/chimney.  Start on the arete left of the route to reach and clip the first bolt, then follow the protection and bolts to the chains shared with Leap Frog.
content.protection: Bolts and gear up to 1".  Chain anchors shared with Leap Frog.

content.description: This route starts on the north-facing slab to the right of Cheers, on the left side of a gap/chimney.  Start straight up the slab on easy climbing to the first bolt, then follow the pro to the chains shared with Lichen.
content.protection: 3-4 bolts, gear to 2", Chain anchors shared with Lichen.

content.description: This is an north-west facing arete around the corner west of Cheers -- the arete to the right of Wheres Mike.  Follow the bolts with good hands and feet.  Protection is easy to place from good stances.  Watch out for loose rock on this one.  Long chains at the top.  This route got its name from the nutcase pilot that was buzzing the ridges in the area while the route was being developed.
content.protection: Mixed.  3 bolts and gear to 1".  I placed a #5 stopper and a Yellow Alien.  Chain anchors.

content.description: Short route, some fun moves on nice edges but only for about 20 feet, then easy to top.
content.location: 2nd route from right end of Brickyard (first wall at the end of the trail).

content.description: Fun Face climb with thin moves and a few finger pockets.
content.protection: Bolts to a Rap Bolt/Chain anchor

content.description:
I called this a "trad" route because there is a significant runout from the last bolt to the chains (on very easy ground) that is protect-able with a nut or cam.  Without that gear, there is potential for a possible ground-fall; however a confident 5.9 leader may safely choose to skip this nut placement. 

  Crux comes just as you pass the first bolt and is well protected.  Fun climbing up the corner to easier ground above.  3 or 4 bolts to long runout to chains.  Though the runout is on very easy ground, there is a crack that takes finger-sized nuts so you might as well stick one in there. Shares chains with Input (right) and Branch Breaker (left).
content.protection: 3 or 4 bolts and a medium (.75" to 1") nut or offset nut.  Chains to rappel (shared with climbs to the right and left).
content.location: Starts just right of a dead/burnt tree; climbing an obvious corner on the right side of Brickyard wall (first wall that the trail hits).

content.description: The crux is above a big ledge. Having an attentive belayer is good here till you clip the 3rd bolt. After the short crux climbing is easy 5.9 on excellent rock.

The crux is down low and above a ledge with dicey pro.The moment your out of the crux stand on a big ledge where you will encounter a short offwidth.This offwidth is very secure, but wear pants because its pretty rough on the right knee! This crack is the most obvious line that goes up the middle of a bright green face.You'll notice this face from the Prison Camp parking lot on the left.Squeezing The Lemmon II... by Eric Rhicard says, this crack has been climbed but does not know by whom or when or how hard it is.This climb is #2 on the Boothill topo!
content.protection: Tcu's, nuts and Camalots to #4. Chain Anchors.

content.description: This is a very fun sporty, short climb near the left end of the boot hill climbs.  It is just left of the climb hollowpoint on the same face.  Although it is not much to look at it does have some very fun moves on the slightly overhanging face.
This route climbs over well-bolted roof onto easier slab above.  Vertically challenged climbers may release "Funky Noises" during the fun roof move.
content.location: The main branch in the trail will take you to "the Brickyard" area. Featuring a prominent roof, this route is near the center of the area (in between "Dirty Woman" and "Branch Breaker").  I will get a photo next time I'm there.

content.description: Great sport route with a tricky start.  The only downfall is that it is short.
content.protection: Sport route with a chain/rap bolt anchor.

content.description: Climb past some bulges down low. Eases up toward the top.  "Trad" only because of the 20-30 feet between the last bolt and the chains. You could protect this part with a medium cam or two.
content.protection: 4 bolts. Place a medium cam or two between the 4th bolt and the chain anchors, if you wish to protect a runout on easy climbing.
content.location: After scrambling up the gully right of "Dunka Dunk", head south for about 100 meters. This will be the second bolted line your encounter, on a relatively small pinnacle called "Fireplace". Shares anchors with "Reachy Riley" to its left.

content.description: This is the right of the two routes around the corner from Insane Pilot (5.7).  Climbing is on good edges with long pulls between.  Well worth climbing.

This is the first of two routes to the right and around the corner from Insane Pilot (5.7.  It starts out on a slab and slowly transfers to vertical climbing through hard to spot holds.  There are several fun moves off of underclings.  The route is well bolted and worth climbing.

This route is about 6 feet to the right of Fat Tire (labeled route 9 on the overview topo).  Start in a thin seam that protects by a small nut and small cam.  Climb to the short right facing dihedral and top out on the Fat Tire anchors.
content.protection: light rack with a RP and a small cam for the start

content.description: The route is right when you arrive at the base from the approach trail.  The Route climbs and steps right over corners.  The route is considerably harder if you go straight up.

According to an old topo, this route in on Fireplace and is to the right of "F...n' Battery". I'm not sure where this route ends. There didn't appear to be anchors on the right side of the pinnacle, so to lower, you'd have to traverse left over to the anchors for "Reachy Riley" and "F...n' Battery." Either that, or make a gear anchor, belay up a follower, and then transfer over to the chain anchors.
content.protection: 1 bolt. The rest is gear. You'll have to lower/rap from the chains of "Reachy Riley" and "F...n' Battery".
content.location: After scrambling up the gully left of "Dunka Dunk", head south for about 100 meters. This will be the right-most line your encounter, on a relatively small pinnacle called "Fireplace". It appears to be all gear except for one bolt about 25 feet up.

content.description: This route is worth the hike up the hill to get to it.  Its a pumpy vertical to slightly overhung face with thin ledges for feet and hands and bomber hand holds right where and when you need them.  Turn right at the top of the trail and look for an obvious west facing triangular face (narrow on the bottom and wider at the top) with two sets of chains in the middle and the left top.  There is a slab on the right side of the route.  Boulder up the slab to clip the first bolt, then step across onto the face, or back down and do it from the bottom with a TR from the first bolt.  Resist the urge to go straight up from the bottom on lead - it is 10a/b moves on very questionable rock.  Follow the bolts, staying mostly to the right. You are heading for the set of chains just left of the angled crack at middle of the wall.
Short climb with a fun start.
content.protection: Bolted sport route with rap bolt/chain anchor.

content.description: This route is on the same buttress as Cheers.  It starts on the north face and rotates around onto the west face after the third bolt.  The overhanging sections and small roofs make this look harder than it is, but bomber jugs can be found for most of the daunting moves.  See Cheers for directions to the rock and a photographic topo.
content.protection: 6 bolts, chains.  Use a two foot runner on the third bolt to reduce rope drag.

content.description: The start could be called anything between 5.9 and 5.10. The last half is about 5.8 or 5.9. The climb to the chains above the last bolt has some good runout but is easier slab climbing as oposed to the technical start. I am not that good yet with understanding Arizona ratings though; I thought it was easier than 'cheers'. The first half of this climb is really awesome. -Joseph Stover
content.protection: Bolts, can't remember how many, probably 4-6.

content.description: The crux is near the top.
content.location: This climb is #5 on the Boothill Topo, and is on the same buttress as Spinal Arc.

content.description: Boot Hill is the obvious north-facing cliff above the Prison Camp campground to the southeast. It appears in "Squeezing the Lemmon" on page 135 with a handful of routes developed in 1989 by Doug Lantz and Diane Vetter. More recently (since July 2004), the crag has been adopted and developed by Andy Peter and Steve Kanoza. They have added 29 new routes (5.5 to 5.11), mostly sport and mixed routes with chains or Metolius rap hangers. The rock varies from crumbly to solid - test the holds and watch out for rockfall. The routes are mostly on the north and west faces, so most routes are shady most of the day, but some sunshine can be had in the afternoon. The low elevation and shade should mean comfortable temps for early Spring and late Fall days as well as warm Winter days.
